title: What happens if you guess? - Leigh Nataro

multiple-choice.question: What is the fundamental counting principle in probability?

options.label: A
options.text: The probability of an event is equal to the number of favorable outcomes divided by the total number of outcomes.

options.label: B
options.text: If there are A possible outcomes for one event, and B possible outcomes for another event, then there are A times B ways to pair the outcomes.

options.label: C
options.text: The probability of an event is equal to the number of unfavorable outcomes divided by the total number of outcomes.

options.label: D
options.text: If there are A possible outcomes for one event, and B possible outcomes for another event, then there are A plus B ways to pair the outcomes.

multiple-choice.question: What is the probability of getting a perfect score by guessing on a 10-question true/false quiz?
What is the expected average score if you and all your friends were to always randomly guess at every question on a 10-question true/false quiz?
If there are 20 questions on a test and five possible answers for each question, what is the probability of getting all 20 questions correct by randomly guessing?
What is the expected number of questions you would get right by guessing on a 20-question test with five possible answers for each question?
What is the term used to describe the type of narrative that connects people and makes a story timeless and humanistic?
According to the transcript, what are the three components of sourcing required in every well-reported piece of journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: Official sources, unofficial sources, and social media

options.label: B
options.text: Official sources, overview sources, and unofficial sources

multiple-choice.question: What type of sources are academics, consultants, and authors considered in the context of journalism?
According to the transcript, what is the purpose of asking surprising questions in journalism?

options.label: B
options.text: To create a sense of urgency in the story

options.label: C
options.text: To convey bulleted facts and updates

options.label: D
options.text: To achieve a complicated, fragile human connection

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the type of story that has the luxury of a slow dance of information and is memorable?

title: How fiction can change reality - Jessica Wise

multiple-choice.question: According to Emily Dickinson, what is the best way to travel to new lands?
What was significant about Samuel Richardson's novel "Pamela" when it was first published?

options.label: A
options.text: It was the first novel to feature a male protagonist.

options.label: B
options.text: It was the first novel to challenge traditional notions of class and marriage.

options.label: C
options.text: It was the first novel to be written by a woman.

options.label: D
options.text: It was the first novel to be published in the 18th century.

multiple-choice.question: According to some scholars, what influenced Charles Darwin's theory of evolution?

options.label: A
options.text: The plots of novels he read and loved

options.label: B
options.text: The scientific discoveries of his time

options.label: C
options.text: The philosophical ideas of ancient Greece

options.label: D
options.text: The observations of nature he made during his travels

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of recent studies that challenge the traditional notion of the hero?

options.label: A
options.text: That humans are hardwired for competition and individualism.

options.label: B
options.text: That humans are members of a shared quest and should work together.

options.label: C
options.text: That humans are shaped by their environment and culture.

options.label: D
options.text: That humans are inherently selfish and only care about themselves.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author suggesting that readers should do when reading classic novels?

options.label: A
options.text: They should only read classic novels and ignore modern literature.

options.label: B
options.text: They should read classic novels, but also keep in mind that the terrain has changed and new perspectives are needed.

options.label: C
options.text: They should only read modern literature and ignore classic novels.

options.label: D
options.text: They should read classic novels, but only for entertainment purposes and not for any deeper meaning.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main purpose of using logarithms in mathematics?

options.label: B
options.text: To deal with extremely small or large numbers

options.label: C
options.text: To calculate the area of shapes

multiple-choice.question: What is the logarithm of a number n, in terms of an exponential equation?

options.label: A
options.text: The base number raised to the power of n

options.label: B
options.text: The exponent to which the base number is raised to equal n

options.label: C
options.text: The product of the base number and n

options.label: D
options.text: The quotient of the base number and n

multiple-choice.question: What is the value of log base 10 of 10,000?
What is the formula for calculating the pH of a water sample?

options.label: A
options.text: pH = log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration

options.label: B
options.text: pH = negative log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration

multiple-choice.question: Why do logarithms help explain why some swimming pools cause red eyes?

options.label: A
options.text: Because logarithms can calculate the pH of water samples

options.label: B
options.text: Because logarithms can calculate the temperature of water samples

options.label: C
options.text: Because logarithms can calculate the volume of water samples

options.label: D
options.text: Because logarithms can calculate the density of water samples

title: The history of keeping time - Karen Mensing

multiple-choice.question: What was the first form of telling time?
What is the object that casts a shadow in a sundial called?
Why were hourglasses commonly used on board ships?

options.label: A
options.text: They were more accurate than sundials

options.label: B
options.text: They were less expensive than mechanical clocks

options.label: C
options.text: The motion of the boat did not affect the hourglass

options.label: D
options.text: They were easier to read than candles

multiple-choice.question: What is the basis for scientific time today?

options.label: A
options.text: Continuous count of seconds based on atomic clocks

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to keep track of time?

options.label: A
options.text: So we can accurately predict the weather

options.label: B
options.text: So we can communicate with people all over the world

options.label: C
options.text: So we can keep track of our daily schedules
